<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>More intuitively, this probability distribution can also be viewed as a cumulative distribution function:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">cdf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lambda_param</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">n</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="n">cdf</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span>
  <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">cdf</span> <span class="o">+=</span> <span class="n">probability</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lambda_param</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">cdf</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">plot_cdf_actor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="n">lambda_param</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lambda_actors</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">lambda_actors</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">primaryName</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"lambda"</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
  <span class="n">n_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">40</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">41</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">probability_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">cdf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lambda_param</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">n</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">n</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">n_list</span><span class="p">])</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">probability_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'firebrick'</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fill_between</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">probability_list</span><span class="p">,</span>  <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'firebrick'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">alpha</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_yticks</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">))</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_facecolor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"linen"</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">grid</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'white'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1.5</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_axisbelow</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">plot_cdf_actors</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">k</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">))</span>
  <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">zip</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ravel</span><span class="p">(),</span> <span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">plot_cdf_actor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">delaxes</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ravel</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">])</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">suptitle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Probability of appearing in more than n movies in t = "</span><span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span><span class="s2">" years"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1.1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tight_layout</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This plot tells use for instance that the probability to appear in more than 10 movies between 1960 and 1969 is roughly 40% for Bette Davis, 85% for Cary Grant and 100% for Robert Mitchum.</p>
<p>Another benefit of the Poisson distribution is that it also brings interesting results for the waiting time between two movies. Indeed, with our previous notation, the waiting time for an actor $a$ follows an exponential distribution of parameter $\lambda_a$. This tells of for instance that the average waiting time between two movies for actor $a$ is $1/\lambda_a$.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">waiting_time</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lambda_param</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">lambda_param</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">lambda_param</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">plot_waiting_time_actor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="n">lambda_param</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">lambda_actors</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">lambda_actors</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">primaryName</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"lambda"</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
  <span class="n">t_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dtype</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">waiting_time_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">waiting_time</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lambda_param</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">t</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">t_list</span><span class="p">])</span>
  <span class="n">x_axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="s2">"-"</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="s2">" y"</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">t</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">t_list</span><span class="p">]</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_axis</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">waiting_time_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'firebrick'</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_yticks</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">))</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_facecolor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"linen"</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">grid</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'y'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'white'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1.5</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_axisbelow</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">plot_waiting_time_actors</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">k</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">))</span>
  <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">zip</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ravel</span><span class="p">(),</span> <span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">plot_waiting_time_actor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">delaxes</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ravel</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">])</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">suptitle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Probability distribution of waiting time between two movies in years"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1.1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tight_layout</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>From the plot above, we can read that there is a 90% probability that Robert Mitchum waits less than a year to make another movie, whereas it is only 20% for Vivien Leigh.</p>
<p>As we can see from this section, despite the model's simplicity, it has a lot of informative and interpretational power, which is why it is such a convenient tool for analytics. Let us now move on to actually evaluating it.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>By definition, the Poisson process is unbiased. The expected number of movies for 10 years will always be equal to the number of movies in the train period.</p>
<p>However, the main part we want to assess in this model is how well it is calibrated. If the model is well calibrated, then for any $k = 0, 1, ...$, we should have $S_{k,t} = \sum_a P[N_{a,t} = k]$ where $S_{k,t}$ is the number of movies made by all active actors after $t$.</p>
<p>In less mathematical terms, it means that if the model claims that for a given actor, there are x% chances to participate in k movies, it really happens with x% probability. The difficulty is that it cannot be assessed an individual level, only at an aggregate level. If most active actors have a high probability to make 0 movies in $t$ years, then we should expect a large number of actors to indeed make 0 movies in $t$ years.</p>
<p>Let us have a look at how well the model is calibrated on the train period first.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">compute_prediction</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">lambda_actors</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"lambda"</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">exp</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">math</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">factorial</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">))</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">total_training</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">movie_counts</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'primaryName'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s1">'numberMovies'</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s1">'sum'</span><span class="p">})</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"primaryName"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">how</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"right"</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s1">'count'</span><span class="p">})</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">})</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">total_training</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">total_training</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">arange</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">41</span><span class="p">)}),</span> <span class="n">how</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"right"</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort_values</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">t</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span>
<span class="n">width</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.3</span>
<span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">8</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">x_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">arange</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">41</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">prediction_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">compute_prediction</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">n</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">x_list</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">prediction_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">width</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"predictions"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Prediction of the number of movies between 1950 and 1959 - Training period"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1.1</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_list</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">width</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">total_training</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">width</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"observed counts"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"upper right"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

cVFm3l+yDktR/LBnHzFY2w2Dt+2Dtd0weNs+WNsNg7ftg7Xd0A/aXvQkfEmSJJU/BClJkjToGcAk
SZIKM4BR/TxSRDwcETMj4sTerk9JETErIu6NiBkRMb2367MsRcRFEfFMRNzXULZmRNwYEY/W/9fo
zTouC220++SIeLLe7jMiYtferOOyEBEbRMTNEfFARNwfESfU5YNhm7fV9gG93SNiWETcGRF/qtv9
pbp8dETcUe/jL68vAhtQ2mn7xRHxeMM2n9DbdV0WImJIRPwxIn5aD/f5bT7oA1jDzyN9EBgL7BsR
Y3u3VsXtmJkT+vo9U3rAxcAuTWUnAr/MzI2BX9bDA83FLNlugDPq7T4hM28oXKcSFgKfyMyxwLbA
sfV7ezBs87baDgN7u/8deG9mbg5MAHaJiG2B06ja/Q7gb8BhvVjHZaWttgN8qmGbz+i9Ki5TJwAP
Ngz3+W0+6AMYDT+PlJn/AFp+HkkDTGbeCjzfVLwH8P368feBDxetVAFttHvAy8y5mfmH+vFLVDvn
9Rkc27yttg9oWXm5Hlyu/kvgvcCVdflA3eZttX3Ai4iRwIeA79bDQT/Y5gawaqc0u2F4DoNgR9Ug
gV9ExN31T0ANNutk5tz68V+BdXqzMoUdFxH31IcoB9xhuEYRMQrYAriDQbbNm9oOA3y714eiZgDP
ADcCjwEvZObCepIBu49vbntmtmzzU+ptfkZErNCLVVxWzgQ+DSyqh9eiH2xzA5i2y8wtqQ7BHhsR
O/R2hXpLVvdkGRTfGIFvA2+nOlQxF/hG71Zn2YmIlYGrgI9n5ouN4wb6Nm+l7QN+u2fm65k5geqX
ViYB7+zlKhXT3PaIGAd8luo52BpYE/hML1axx0XEbsAzmXl3b9elswxgg/znkTLzyfr/M8DVVDus
weTpiFgXoP7/TC/Xp4jMfLreWS8CLmCAbveIWI4qgFySmT+uiwfFNm+t7YNluwNk5gvAzcC7gdUj
ouXG4wN+H9/Q9l3qw9GZmX8HvsfA2+aTgd0jYhbVKUTvBc6iH2xzA9gg/nmkiFgpIlZpeQzsDNzX
/lwDznXAQfXjg4Bre7EuxbQEkNqeDMDtXp8HciHwYGae3jBqwG/ztto+0Ld7RIyIiNXrx8OB91Od
/3YzsFc92UDd5q21/aGGLxtBdR7UgNrmmfnZzByZmaOoPr9/lZn70Q+2uXfCB+pLsc/kjZ9HOqWX
q1RERLyNqtcLqp+lmjaQ2x4RlwJTgLWBp4GTgGuAK4ANgb8Ae2fmgDphvY12T6E6DJXALOCohvOi
BoSI2A74DXAvb5wb8jmqc6EG+jZvq+37MoC3e0SMpzrheghVB8MVmfnlel93GdUhuD8C+9c9QgNG
O23/FTACCGAG8LGGk/UHlIiYAnwyM3frD9vcACZJklSYhyAlSZIKM4BJkiQVZgCTJEkqzAAmSZJU
mAFMkiSpMAOYJElSYQYwSZKkwv5/J6KKAjN0kt4AAAAASUVORK5CYII=
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Looking at the plot above, we can see that on the train data, the Poisson process is very well calibrated. For most number of movies, the prediction is correct. There is only a slight overestimation of the number of actors that did 0 movies, combined to an underestimation of the number of actors that did 1 movie.</p>
<p>To assess the goodness of fit on the train period, we can use regression metrics like Mean Squared Error, Mean Absolute Error or the R2 score to measure the difference between these aggregated counts:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">mse</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">total_training</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">prediction_list</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">mae</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">total_training</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">prediction_list</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">r2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">total_training</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">prediction_list</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Fit on the train period: </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"- Mean Squared Error: </span><span class="si">%i</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="k">mse</span>)
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"- Mean Absolute Error: </span><span class="si">%.1f</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="k">mae</span>)
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"- R2: </span><span class="si">%.2f</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="k">r2</span>)
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Fit on the train period: 

- Mean Squared Error: 5606
- Mean Absolute Error: 22.9
- R2: 0.93
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Thus, the model we chose turns out to fit the train period quite well.</p>
<p>However, when looking at the test period (the next decade), it is a totally different story, as our model grossly overestimates the number of movies made between 1960 and 1969.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">t</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span>

<span class="n">real_amount</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">movie_counts_validation</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Number of movies made between 1960 and 1969 in reality: </span><span class="si">%i</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">real_amount</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">total_prediction</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lambda_actors</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"lambda"</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">t</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Expected number of movies made between 1960 and 1969 (Poisson model): </span><span class="si">%i</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">total_prediction</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Number of movies made between 1960 and 1969 in reality: 17094
Expected number of movies made between 1960 and 1969 (Poisson model): 33656
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>What happened? Why are we suddenly overestimating by 95% the expected number of movies?</p>
<p>The answer to this question is actually simple: the Poisson process assumes that actors will keep making movies at the same rate... forever. Remember, what we called "active actors" are actors that made at least a movie in 1945-1949. We learned their rate $\lambda_a$ during 1950-1959. It is highly doubtful they would still be making movies at this rate in 1960-1969, or even just highly unlikely they would still all be active by then...</p>
<p>Let us have a closer look at the calibration of the model for the test period:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">total_validation</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">movie_counts_validation</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'primaryName'</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s1">'numberMovies'</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s1">'sum'</span><span class="p">})</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"primaryName"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">how</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"right"</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s1">'count'</span><span class="p">})</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">})</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">total_validation</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">total_validation</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">arange</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">41</span><span class="p">)}),</span> <span class="n">how</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"right"</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort_values</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">by</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">width</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.3</span>
<span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">8</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">x_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">arange</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">41</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">prediction_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">compute_prediction</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">t</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">n</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">x_list</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">prediction_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">width</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"predictions"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Prediction of the number of movies between 1960 and 1969 - Test period"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1.1</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_list</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">width</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">total_validation</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">width</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"observed counts"</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"upper right"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[0]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x7f1ddb796a90></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>

YAAccwOYdsnM7WkuwR4XEW/u6wr1hWy+j2XIfGIEvgq8juZyxTzgv/q2OqtORKwFfA/4aGY+17ps
MB/3Dto9JI55Zr6YmRNo/tPKJGCrPq5SFe3bHRFbA5+iaf+OwPrAJ/uwiqtEROwNPJmZd/V1XZaX
AWyI/3ukzHys/H4SuJrmhDVUPBERrwEov5/s4/pUk5lPlBP2UuACBulxj4gRNCHk0sz8fpk96I97
R+0eKse8TWY+C9wCvBFYNyLavnh8UJ/jW9q9Z7kcnZn5F+BiBucxnwzsExGzaYYQvRU4mwFwzA1g

HiLHfFRErFserwG8g2YM3C3A/mW1wXjMO2r3Ay0fNIJmDNSgO+aZ+anM3CQzR9O8f9+cmQczAI65
34QPlNuxz+Lv/x7ptD6uUhUR8Y80vV7Q/FuqywZr2yPiO8BuwIbAE8BngWuAK4HXAn8ADsjMQTdY
vZO270ZzKSqB2cCHWsZFDQoRsQvwc+Ae/j425NM046EG7XHvot0HMfiP+XiaAdfDaDoYrszMz5dz
3eU0l+F+AxxSeoUGhS7afTMwCghgBvDhlsH6g05E7AaclJl7D4RjbgCTJEmqzEuQkiRJlRnAJEmS
KjOASZIkVWYAkyRJqswAJkmSVJkBTJIkqTIDmCRJUmX/D8Rxj1G3YmgfAAAAAElFTkSuQmCC
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This plot confirms what we started explaining above: more than 3000 actors made no movies at all in 1960-1969, although this only happened to less than 2000 in 1950-1959. However, this change is not captured by the Poisson process, that still predicts the same values for this decade than the previous one.</p>
<p>As a result, all the fit metrics are much worse on the test period than on the train period:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">mse</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">total_validation</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">prediction_list</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">mae</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">total_validation</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">prediction_list</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">r2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">total_validation</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"count"</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">prediction_list</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Fit on the test period: </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"- Mean Squared Error: </span><span class="si">%i</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="k">mse</span>)
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"- Mean Absolute Error: </span><span class="si">%.1f</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="k">mae</span>)
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"- R2: </span><span class="si">%.2f</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span><span class="k">r2</span>)
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Fit on the test period: 

- Mean Squared Error: 31958
- Mean Absolute Error: 63.9
- R2: 0.87
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>From this evaluation, it is clear that the Poisson process we suggested as a first approach is way too simplistic because it wrongly assumes that actors remain active forever, which leads to systematic activity overestimation. Moreover, this overestimation can only get worse with time: had we looked at 1970-1979 as a test period, it would obviously have been even more problematic.</p>
<p>As a result, we need to correct this model by adding a dynamic component to it that would capture decrease in activity over time, which would better reflect reality.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="5.-Fitting-a-Pareto/NBD-model">5. Fitting a Pareto/NBD model<a class="anchor-link" href="#5.-Fitting-a-Pareto/NBD-model">¶</a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Model-Specification">Model Specification<a class="anchor-link" href="#Model-Specification">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A good alternative to the Poisson process is provided to us by marketing literature, as you can draw analogies between our setting and common marketing problems. "How many movies do actors make?" can turn into "How many deals does this customer make with my company?", and "Which actor is still active?" can translate as "How many of my customers are still active?" These questions were fundamental in the elaboration of the Pareto/NBD model, presented by Schmittlein et al in <a href= 'https://www.jstor.org/stable/2631608?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents'>Counting your customers: who are they and what will they do next?" (1987)</a>.</p>
<p>The Pareto/NBD model builds on the Poisson process to add a second latent dimension: whether at time $t$, the actor is still active. That way, we do solve for the missing part observed previously, as we now allow actors to be active for a limited amount of time. In the Pareto/NBD model, we follow a two steps approach. First, is the actor still active? If yes, then we can apply the Poisson process as before. This model makes sense from an intuitive point of view, but estimating at what time an actor stops being active is difficult, as we do not observe at what point an actor effectively stops being active (unless death occurs).</p>
<p>Mathematically speaking, this is how we formulate the setting (skip this section if you are not so keen on stats overloads):</p>
<ul>
<li>An actor's "lifetime" is modeled with an exponential distribution of "death rate" $\mu_a$ </li>
<li>Conditionally on being active, the actor still follows the Poisson process of rate $\lambda_a$</li>
</ul>
<p>One of the main statistical differences between this model and the Poisson process is that we now place ourselves in the Hierarchical Bayesian framework and assume that all $\mu_a$ and $\lambda_a$ parameters also follow prior distributions:</p>
<ul>
<li>The "death rates" $\mu_a$ follow a Gamma distribution of parameters $(s,\beta)$</li>
<li>The activity rates $\lambda_a$ follow a Gamma distribution of parameters $(r,\alpha)$</li>
<li>For each actor, we assume $\mu_a$ and $\lambda_a$ to be independent. </li>
</ul>
<p>The Exponential-Gamma model for $\mu_a$ results in a Pareto distribution and the Poisson-Gamma model for $\lambda_a$ in a Negative Binomial distribution, hence the name Pareto/NBD. We will not fully write out the formulas of the model here as they quickly get long, however, they are all detailed in Schmittlein et al's paper.</p>
<p>In this setting, an actor's behavior is defined by $(\mu_a,\lambda_a)$, which are functions of each actor's data and prior parameters $(s,\beta,r,\alpha)$. Hence, we actually fully characterize our model with only 4 parameters. The main advantage of the Bayesian approach in this context is that the modeling for each actor will be impacted by the behavior of other actors, while still allowing for heterogeneity across the sample. For instance, it allows us to learn from the whole panel at what rate an actor typically becomes inactive. This is critical: how else could we predict that an actor who was very active in 1950-1959 could then suddenly stop making movies somewhere in the 1960's?</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Training-the-model-using-the-"lifetimes"-package">Training the model using the "lifetimes" package<a class="anchor-link" href="#Training-the-model-using-the-"lifetimes"-package">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Fortunately, the "lifetimes" package spares us the parameter estimation for this problem, which otherwise would be quite tedious. To use the package, we need to convert our data to a dataframe with 3 attributes per actor:</p>
<ul>
<li>frequency: number of movies in 1950-1959 (train period)</li>
<li>recency: the year of the last movie</li>
<li>T: the number of years in the train period (10 in our case)</li>
</ul>
<p>To comply with the package's notation, the year last year of the train period - 1949 - represents now year 0. This is what we eventually get:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">movie_counts</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"primaryName"</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s1">'sum'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"startYear"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s1">'max'</span><span class="p">})</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s2">"startYear"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s2">"recency"</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s2">"numberMovies"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s2">"frequency"</span><span class="p">})</span>
<span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"primaryName"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">how</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s2">"right"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"recency"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">recency</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">startYear</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1</span>
<span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">inplace</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"T"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">endYear</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="n">startYear</span>
<span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">primaryName</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isin</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">)]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[0]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>With this dataframe in hand, all we need to do is to pass it to the ParetoNBDFitter.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pnbd</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ParetoNBDFitter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">penalizer_coef</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.1</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'frequency'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'recency'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">movie_counts_reshape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'T'</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[0]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><lifetimes.ParetoNBDFitter: fitted with 5669 subjects, alpha: 0.77, beta: 36.91, r: 0.52, s: 1.17></pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Parameter estimation of the Pareto/NBD model: </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Parameter estimation of the Pareto/NBD model: 

r         0.516550
alpha     0.772287
s         1.166683
beta     36.909324
dtype: float64
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Model-Interpretation">Model Interpretation<a class="anchor-link" href="#Model-Interpretation">¶</a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let us first have a look at the four parameters estimated above: $(r, \alpha, s, \beta)$. These parameters allow us to specify the two gamma distributions (priors) from which all the $\lambda_a$ and $\mu_a$ values are drawn.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">lambda_x_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">gamma</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ppf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.05</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">scale</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'alpha'</span><span class="p">]),</span> 
                                <span class="n">gamma</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ppf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.95</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">scale</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'alpha'</span><span class="p">]),</span> <span class="mi">1000</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">mu_x_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">gamma</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ppf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.01</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'s'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">scale</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'beta'</span><span class="p">]),</span> 
                                <span class="n">gamma</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ppf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.99</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'s'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">scale</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'beta'</span><span class="p">]),</span> <span class="mi">1000</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">lambda_y_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">gamma</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pdf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lambda_x_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">scale</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'alpha'</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">mu_y_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">gamma</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pdf</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mu_x_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'s'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">scale</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'beta'</span><span class="p">])</span>

<span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">axes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">lambda_x_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">lambda_y_list</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">axes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Probability distribution of the </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> lambda parameters"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">axes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mu_x_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mu_y_list</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">axes</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Probability distribution of the </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> mu parameters"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[0]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Probability distribution of the \n mu parameters')</pre>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">mean_lambda_a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'alpha'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">mean_mu_a</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'s'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">params_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'beta'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Among all actors, the mean 'activity rate' lambda_a is: </span><span class="si">%.2f</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">mean_lambda_a</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Among all actors, the mean 'death rate' mu_a is: </span><span class="si">%.2f</span><span class="s2">"</span> <span class="o">%</span> <span class="n">mean_mu_a</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Among all actors, the mean 'activity rate' lambda_a is: 0.67
Among all actors, the mean 'death rate' mu_a is: 0.03
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As you can tell from these two distribution plots, the $\mu_a$ parameters are very concentrated around the mode at $0.01$. The $\lambda_a$ parameters, on the other hand, are drawn from a gamma distribution that allows a wider range of values. In other words, the Pareto/NBD model suggests that while actors might differ a lot in terms of movie frequency, they are very similar in the way they end their career.</p>
<p>The very different shapes of the two distribution plots illustrate why the Gamma distribution is such a popular choice for priors in Bayesian analysis, as it allows to fit very data sets of very different shapes.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Let us now have a closer look at the probability to be active, which is the key feature of the Pareto/NBD model compared to the more naive Poisson model. The implications of this model is that the longer it has been since an actor made his or her last movie, the more likely it is that the actor now is inactive.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">t_future</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">plot_p_alive_actor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="n">history_actor</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">movie_counts</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">movie_counts</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">primaryName</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">]</span>
  <span class="n">history_actor</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">startYear</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_datetime</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">history_actor</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">startYear</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">format</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'%Y'</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">plot_history_alive</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">t_future</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">history_actor</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'startYear'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">freq</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'YS'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">start_date</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'1950'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'lower left'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">labels</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'P_alive'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'movies'</span><span class="p">])</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">plot_p_alive_actors</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">):</span>
  <span class="n">n</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">k</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="p">))</span>
  <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">zip</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ravel</span><span class="p">(),</span> <span class="n">actors</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sca</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">plot_p_alive_actor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ax</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">actor_name</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">k</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">delaxes</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">axes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ravel</span><span class="p">()[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">])</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">suptitle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Probability of being active during the training period"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">1.1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
  <span class="n">fig</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tight_layout</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In the Pareto/NBD model, an actor's probability to be still active is mainly driven by the recency of the last movie. However, it is also connected to the actor's frequency. This twofold dependency can be visualized in the heatmap below. For instance, observing the last movie in the train period was in 1957 (year 8 in the model) will not mean that much if the actor used to make very little movies before that and that we observed several such gaps before. On the other hand, if an actor used to make a lot of movies in the past but suddenly stopped in 1957, it is much more likely that this is because it stopped active. This explains the characteristic shape of the heatmap.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plot_probability_alive_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Probability Actor is Alive, </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> by Frequency and Recency of the movies"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Actor's Historical Frequency"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Actor's Recency"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As a result, the Pareto/NBD model assumes that the more movies an actor has made in the train period and the more recent the last movie was, the more movies this actor is likely to make in the next period. The heatmap below illustrates this double dependency and has the same characteristic shape as previously.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [0]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plot_frequency_recency_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pnbd</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Expected Number of Future Movies per Year, </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> by Frequency and Recency of the movies"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Actor's Historical Frequency"</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Actor's Recency"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[0]:</div>
